This afternoon, Brentwood UFSD was mistakenly included in a list, released by Governor Cuomo, of 107 school districts that allegedly did not submit reopening plans for the 2020-21 school year as required by the state. The Brentwood Union Free School District submitted its reopening plan document to both the New York State Education Department and New York State Department of Health prior to the July 31 deadline and also posted it to the district's website, as required. The Governor’s Office, as well as the NYSED and NYSDOH, have been notified of this error and asked to correct the situation as expeditiously as possible.

Mr. Richard Loeschner
Superintendent of Schools

Brentwood Students Pay it Forward

“It’s on me.” Those are words you typically don’t hear from strangers when buying food, but sometimes those strangers are Brentwood students. Three teens from Brentwood, Diego Agreda, Kevon Vasquez and Ashton Ali, spent their Friday—and hard-earned money—on Bagel Boss customers. Bagel Boss patrons were overcome with emotion and gratitude when the teens insisted on paying for their meals. The boys have gone viral for their efforts, and the Brentwood School District could not be prouder.

Recognizing their own past financial struggles and the hardships of the current economy, the three boys were determined to put a smile on people’s faces. “If I got a dollar in my bank account, and they need that, I will give it to them.” We teach our students so much in their time in the district, yet we often find ourselves learning from them in moments like this. Thank you, Diego, Kevon, and Ashton for your kindness and generosity. Newsday

https://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/coronavirus/acts-of-kindness/brentwood-teens-buy-food-strangers-1.45932842

An Important Message from Mr. Richard Loeschner, Superintendent of Schools

Brentwood Community,

This is the last full week of distance learning. Next Wednesday, June 17th will be the final day for all students from K-12. I must commend and thank all of the students, parents, teachers and administrators who have worked tirelessly since March 13th. We have been through a lot together over these last months and we have learned a great deal about our strengths and weaknesses as a school community and I am certain next year we will be stronger because of the experience. Please continue to pray and care for so many of our neighbors, co-workers and friends who continue to suffer with loss and pain from the coronavirus. Finally, in this time of civic unrest, let's continue to do what the Brentwood Community does best—listen carefully and hear other people's concerns and criticisms because only when we look to improve individually can we hope to improve our communities.

Thank you and have a great week and we look forward to seeing everyone soon. #BrentwoodProud #BrentwoodStrong

If you are struggling or need assistance, please refer to our district website for a variety of helpful resources that are available and please do not hesitate to reach out to your building principal or a member of district administration. We thank you for your patience and support.

Be well,

Mr. Richard Loeschner
Superintendent of Schools

No Labels Attached

Brentwood’s students in Mr. Sequoyah Wharton’s Media Communications/Broadcast TV class are breaking down the narratives around stereotypes and misconceptions for the PBS NewsHour’s Student Reporting Labs. With new gear—Canon camera and apparel generously donated by PBS PBS NewsHour—students will conduct interviews with their peers to discuss a time when students in the building felt misunderstood, labeled or stereotyped. Afterwards, the raw footage will be distilled into small video segments and short clips to be featured on social media and the PBS NewsHour nightly broadcasts. This project-based learning not only allows students to understand stereotyping and each other’s experiences, but to take on the challenge to help change the narrative in our community. Way to go! #BrentwoodProud #BrentwoodStrong #BrentwoodMedia

Rock Your Socks: Celebrating Differences

Students from FJC Southeast Elementary School recently hosted its culminating event for their yearlong initiative; Rock Your Socks. The building’s gymnasium transformed into an interactive workshop for students to network with various guest speakers with different types of impairments, such as hearing, visual, or physical.

Throughout the school year, FJC Southeast Elementary dedicated one day each month to flaunt vibrant, unique, colorful, unmatched socks to spark conversation among students and staff about their differences. On the designated day of each month, teachers and staff organized strategic lesson plans to educate students about physical or visual impairments. This initiative and several other activities teachers implement in each classroom introduce a tolerance of diversity to young leaders in our classrooms, directly aligning with the district’s goal to foster an environment of acceptance and inclusiveness. Way to go, Brentwood! #BrentwoodStong #BrentwoodProud

Thank you, Verizon FiOS1 - Long Island

We are the Change

Students and staff at Brentwood’s Freshman Center took a short hiatus from everyday curriculum to focus on the importance of mental health and emotional stability. Brentwood’s faculty and staff, in partnership with Island Harvest, recently put a fork in hunger during the inauguration of the district’s new food pantry at the high school to assist students who regularly experience food insecurity make ends meet.

Spearheaded by two of Brentwood’s extraordinary teachers, Laura Murphy and Natalia O’Brien, Brentwood’s faculty members collaborated to identify students in need, coordinate a strategic process for students’ accessibility and confidentiality, organize donations and tackle the construction of the pantry. Much of the inventory derived from several donations from Brentwood’s faculty with tremendous help from Island Harvest to fully stock each shelf. The building has a team of six teachers who are paired with three-four students as a point of contact on an as-need basis for access to the pantry. The district thanks the efforts of the following individuals who helped bring the food pantry initiative to fruition! #BrentwoodProud #BrentwoodStrong

Looking Back, Moving Forward

The Brentwood Freshman Center recently welcomed special guests Ruth Mermelstein, 89-year old Holocaust survivor, and Helen Turner, Director of Youth Education at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center (HMTC) of Nassau County to educate students on the historical tragedy and advocate respect for everyone.

Ruth’s inspiring story of perseverance and courage provided our students with a first-hand perspective on the implications of intolerance and insight on how it can be avoided. Leading up to Ruth’s visit, the ninth-grade students worked on projects to learn more about the tragic moment in history, an alarming reminder of the repercussions of intolerance and the dangers of silence and apathy. The district aims to educate students on these unthinkable tragedies in history and guide them to take steps to prevent these events from happening again. Way to go, Brentwood. #BrentwoodProud #BrentwoodStrong

Project GROW Comes to FRUITion at Laurel Park

Laurel Park Elementary School recently celebrated the first hydroponic harvest of the district-wide initiative, Project GROW (Green Resource for Observing Water). Ms. Argueta’s third grade bilingual class was excited to harvest fruits and vegetables from the class’s hydroponic gardens to make kale-strawberry smoothies with Brentwood High School’s science research teacher, Dr. Rebecca Grella.

In October, twelve Brentwood High School students from its acclaimed science research program presented the eleven elementary schools in the district with portable hydroponic grow stations. Over the last few months, Brentwood’s elementary students have had the responsibility of sustaining their units with proper care including timer settings, water levels, and pH Levels. Project GROW has encouraged students to make a proactive effort to be cognizant about improving our ecosystems. Keep up the great work, Laurel Park! #BrentwoodProud

Twelve Brentwood High School students from its acclaimed science research program recently visited Laurel Park Elementary School to celebrate the commencement of a district-wide initiative, Project GROW, to teach the next generation of Brentwood’s science-explorers about hydroponic gardening. Under the supervision of Brentwood’s science and research teacher, Dr. Rebecca Grella, the 12 high school students constructed portable hydroponic grow stations for the eleven elementary schools in the district.
Project GROW is intended to bridge the gap between the high school and elementary schools by fostering supportive mentor relationships between the students through a project and a curriculum aligned with Next Generation Science Standards and pre-existing water lessons from the program’s grant funding source, the Nature Conservancy’s Nature Works Everywhere program.

Oak Park’s students and staff orchestrated an original theatrical performance titled “Being Me in Unity.” In collaboration with a team of talented Oak Park participants, Oak Park Principal Ms. Catandella performed a song, “This is Me.” Along with the play, there was also a special assembly designed to encourage empathy and derail bullying behavior. Students showed their support for bullying prevention by creating Unity Day chains, wearing orange, and reciting the established Oak Park mantras.

The Brentwood Union Free School District’s bilingual students in grades four through eight competed in the District’s third annual NYS Spanish Spelling Bee, held last June. Rising to the top of the competition were students from the District’s East Middle School. This competition goes far beyond a simple test of students’ capacity to memorize words. The students demonstrate their ability to decipher and understand pronunciation, etymology and position of diacritical marks on vocabulary words that will sequentially transfer into the English language.

Three of East Middle School’s students—sixth grader Diana Gonzalez, seventh grader Mirna Vasquez, and eighth grader Cecia Reyes—finished the competition as first place winners in their respective grades. Cecia was also recognized as the overall first place winner of the Brentwood School District Spanish Spelling Bee, and won an all-expense paid trip to the 8th Annual National Spanish Spelling Bee in San Antonio, Texas.

post_text: The Brentwood Union Free School District recently held two assemblies—Girls Inc. and My Brother’s Keeper (MBK)—to ignite the next generation of empowered male and female students in the Brentwood community. The Girls Inc. convocation, exclusive to female students emphasized the development of the whole girl, encouraged female students to value their whole selves, and self-actualize their inner power. Brentwood’s female students also learned about necessary tools for current obstacles females face. The MBK assembly focused on different initiatives for young men of color to ensure they are provided unlimited opportunities to succeed in life and academics.

Brentwood Union Free School District’s South Middle School recently began its National Junior Honor Society (NJHS) tutoring program for the 2018-2019 year. South Middle School’s NJHS members offer one-to-one tutoring sessions for students at Oak Park Elementary School.

The National Junior Honors Society tutoring program motivates and inspires the younger students to stay focused and organized, prioritize, and study more effectively. Brentwood High School recently hosted a one-hour youth empowerment assembly and two-hour leadership summit focused on campus-wide initiatives to combat critical issues and find ways to improve the student atmosphere in the district.

Teen Truth’s youth empowerment assembly tackled several teen related issues prevalent in today’s society including bullying, isolation, suicide, and factors that play a role in some teens choosing violence. Mr. Pohl and students dedicated three hours to develop an action plan that will create a positive atmosphere and improve culture within the school buildings. Following the assembly and summit, members of the high school faculty took the initiative to host a forum with District Administration where they discussed students’ concerns—how they feel, what issues they are dealing with, and how faculty can play a role in the solutions.

post_text: The Brentwood Union Free School District recently partnered with the Central Islip School District to hold a surprise charity tennis match to pay tribute to Brentwood High School varsity tennis coach Brian Rooney’s father, who recently passed away from pancreatic cancer after courageously battling the disease for more than two years. Throughout the match between the two schools, students raised money to support the Lustgarten Foundation and pancreatic cancer research and also decorated a banner that hung on the tennis court fence. This event reflected the close-knit community that exists in Central Islip and Brentwood, and was a testament to the focus on community activism both schools have instilled in their student populations.
